online.game
Class BaseBoard

java.lang.Object
  online.game.BaseBoard
All Implemented Interfaces:
PlayConstants, Digestable
Direct Known Subclasses:
RBoard
public abstract class BaseBoard
extends java.lang.Object
implements PlayConstants, Digestable

this is the recommended lowest level class for Boardspace boards. It contains only a few things that ought to be common to any game board implementation. Subclasses of this class add functions for various types of board geometry, and subclasses of those are generally the actual classes for particular games.

The visible interface which is eventually implemented by a game board is (@link BoardProtocol)

Author:
ddyer
See Also:
gBoard, hexBoard, rectBoard, triBoard, squareBoard, circBoard

win

public boolean[] win
true if player[index] has won. In multiplayer games this is replaced in the board initialization with a longer array instead of 2.

gametype

public java.lang.String gametype
the type of the current game, which is printed into game records and used to create duplicates boards in the "same" mode.

randomKey

public long randomKey
in games with some random initialization, this is the integer used to see the random number sequence. This is normally supplied by the lobby when launching the game.

public final void doInit(java.lang.String game,

doInit

public void doInit(java.lang.String game,
                   long rv)
an overridable method. For games which always have 2 players, this would be the normal "init to start" method. Games with more players or more initialization parameters must override this because this two-argument method is called by clone() when copying a board

Parameters:
game -
rv -

moveNumber

public int moveNumber()
return the current game move number. this is mostly for show, but part of the robot move/unmove logic requires that this number be unwound correctly. Also, changes in move number key line and column changes in the visible game log.

Returns:
an integer

whoseTurn

public int whoseTurn()
return the index of the player whose turn it is. Note that this is not strictly related to the position of players in other arrays. It's just the board's internal index.

Returns:
an integer index representing the current player

DoneState

public boolean DoneState()
return true if the board's current state should allow hitting the "done" key. This method is normally overridden by the game's specific board class.

Returns:
true if the "done" button ought to be active

DigestState

public boolean DigestState()
true true if the board's current state should be digested and saved to check for repetitions.

Returns:
a hash code representing the board state

encodeCellPosition

public java.awt.Point encodeCellPosition(int x,
                                         int y,
                                         double cellsize)
Override this method to encode a cell position within the board. We optionally encode "within the board" coordinates separately so the pointing can take into account features such as zoom, rotate, and perspective. these are normally provided by gBoard, but for a few classes they are not. In those cases, the entire getBoardCoords and getScreenCoords methods would normally be overridden, making these unnecessary. Otherwise, these are necessary because the board itself is usually scalable in size, so raw coordinates need to be scaled.

Parameters:
x -
y -
cellsize -
Returns:
a point representing the mouse position
See Also:
decodeCellPosition(int, int, double)

                                         int y,
                                         double cellsize)
Override this method to decode an encoded board position.

Parameters:

y -
cellsize -
Returns:
a new "point" representing the mouse position
